segment.source: Windows Assessment Services step-by-step guide
segment.target: Windows Assessment Services step-by-step guide

segment.source: Windows Assessment Services step-by-step guide
segment.target: Windows Assessment Services step-by-step guide

segment.source: Windows Assessment Services step-by-step guide
segment.target: Windows Assessment Services step-by-step guide

segment.source: Windows Assessment Services is a test framework that is used to automate quality measurements, such as performance, reliability and functionality, in a lab environment on multiple computers.
segment.target: Windows Assessment Services is a test framework that is used to automate quality measurements, such as performance, reliability and functionality, in a lab environment on multiple computers.

segment.source: The Windows Assessment Services - Client (Windows ASC) is the graphical user interface that is used to manage settings and assets, such as which lab computers to test, which images should be applied to those computers, and which assessments should be used to test the computers.
segment.target: The Windows Assessment Services - Client (Windows ASC) is the graphical user interface that is used to manage settings and assets, such as which lab computers to test, which images should be applied to those computers, and which assessments should be used to test the computers.

segment.source: Windows ASC is also used to monitor the progress of a running job, and to view the results that were produced.
segment.target: Windows ASC is also used to monitor the progress of a running job, and to view the results that were produced.

segment.source: To assess computer or image quality, Windows Assessment Services test framework does the following:
segment.target: To assess computer or image quality, Windows Assessment Services test framework does the following:

segment.source: Automates image deployment to test computers by using Windows Deployment Services (WDS) and a customized Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) image
segment.target: Automates image deployment to test computers by using Windows Deployment Services (WDS) and a customized Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) image

segment.source: Automates the running of assessments by using Windows Remote Management (WinRM)
segment.target: Automates the running of assessments by using Windows Remote Management (WinRM)

segment.source: Automates the collection of results from test computers by using WinRM to copy results to the Windows Assessment Services server.
segment.target: Automates the collection of results from test computers by using WinRM to copy results to the Windows Assessment Services server.

segment.source: The following illustration outlines the Windows Assessment Services topology:
segment.target: The following illustration outlines the Windows Assessment Services topology:

segment.source: windows assessment services topology
segment.target: windows assessment services topology

segment.source: This guide provides step-by-step guidance for installing the Windows Assessment Toolkit, configuring Windows Assessment Services and the Windows ASC, assessing multiple computers, and then reviewing results.
segment.target: This guide provides step-by-step guidance for installing the Windows Assessment Toolkit, configuring Windows Assessment Services and the Windows ASC, assessing multiple computers, and then reviewing results.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: Step 1: Installation and Configuration
segment.target: Step 1: Installation and Configuration

segment.source: Step 2: Create a Project
segment.target: Step 2: Create a Project

segment.source: Step 3: Create a Job
segment.target: Step 3: Create a Job

segment.source: Step 4: Run the Job
segment.target: Step 4: Run the Job

segment.source: Step 5: Review the Results
segment.target: Step 5: Review the Results

segment.source: Conclusion
segment.target: Conclusion

segment.source: Prequisites
segment.target: Prequisites

segment.source: To successfully complete the steps outlined in this guide, verify that you have the following:
segment.target: To successfully complete the steps outlined in this guide, verify that you have the following:

segment.source: Windows Server 2012 with the following:
segment.target: Windows Server 2012 with the following:

segment.source: Recommended: 1 GB NIC
segment.target: Recommended: 1 GB NIC

segment.source: Recommended: Sizable storage space for trace files, results and images
segment.target: Recommended: Sizable storage space for trace files, results and images

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You can use Windows Server 2008 R2 in this scenario.
segment.target: You can use Windows Server 2008 R2 in this scenario.

segment.source: However, Windows Server 2008 R2 does not support Dynamic Driver Provisioning (DDP) as described in step 1 and step 2, where it is used to add NIC drivers and import additional drivers to the driver store.
segment.target: However, Windows Server 2008 R2 does not support Dynamic Driver Provisioning (DDP) as described in step 1 and step 2, where it is used to add NIC drivers and import additional drivers to the driver store.

segment.source: You can work around this by using Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) to add drivers to your Windows image offline.
segment.target: You can work around this by using Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) to add drivers to your Windows image offline.

segment.source: For more information, see Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) Technical Reference.

segment.source: One or more test computers that have the following:
segment.target: One or more test computers that have the following:

segment.source: USB boot support
segment.target: USB boot support

segment.source: Network (PXE) boot support
segment.target: Network (PXE) boot support

segment.source: Network Card driver
segment.target: Network Card driver

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The test computers can be bare metal computers (no operating system installed), or computers that are running Windows 8.
segment.target: The test computers can be bare metal computers (no operating system installed), or computers that are running Windows 8.

segment.source: A Windows 8 image (if you are using bare metal computers)
segment.target: A Windows 8 image (if you are using bare metal computers)

segment.source: A 512 MB USB flash drive
segment.target: A 512 MB USB flash drive

segment.source: All computers must be on the same subnet
segment.target: All computers must be on the same subnet

segment.source: A DHCP server to assign IP addresses to test computers
segment.target: A DHCP server to assign IP addresses to test computers

segment.source: For more information about system requirements, see Installing Windows Assessment Services.
segment.target: For more information about system requirements, see Installing Windows Assessment Services.

segment.source: Step 1: Installation and Configuration
segment.target: Step 1: Installation and Configuration

segment.source: You must install Windows Assessment Services on a server computer, which also installs Windows ASC on the server.
segment.target: You must install Windows Assessment Services on a server computer, which also installs Windows ASC on the server.

segment.source: You can also install a stand-alone version of Windows ASC on a client computer.
segment.target: You can also install a stand-alone version of Windows ASC on a client computer.

segment.source: For more information about how to install Windows Assessment Services and Windows ASC, see Installing Windows Assessment Services.
segment.target: For more information about how to install Windows Assessment Services and Windows ASC, see Installing Windows Assessment Services.

segment.source: Setup and configuration includes the following steps:
segment.target: Setup and configuration includes the following steps:

segment.source: Initializing Windows Assessment Services
segment.target: Initializing Windows Assessment Services

segment.source: Configuring access to symbols
segment.target: Configuring access to symbols

segment.source: Adding NIC Drivers to the Windows PE image that Windows Deplyment Services uses.
segment.target: Adding NIC Drivers to the Windows PE image that Windows Deplyment Services uses.

segment.source: This step is required only when the test computers require out-of-box NIC drivers so that they have network connectivity during inventory or after the Windows image is deployed.
segment.target: This step is required only when the test computers require out-of-box NIC drivers so that they have network connectivity during inventory or after the Windows image is deployed.

segment.source: Preparing the Windows PE USB drive for test computer inventory.
segment.target: Preparing the Windows PE USB drive for test computer inventory.

segment.source: To inventory bare metal computers, you must create a bootable USB drive to start the computer and add it to the inventory.
segment.target: To inventory bare metal computers, you must create a bootable USB drive to start the computer and add it to the inventory.

segment.source: Adding Test computers, images and unattended answer files to the inventory.
segment.target: Adding Test computers, images and unattended answer files to the inventory.

segment.source: Adding out-of-box drivers to the Windows Deployment Services driver store so that they’re available for driver injection during image deployment.
segment.target: Adding out-of-box drivers to the Windows Deployment Services driver store so that they’re available for driver injection during image deployment.

segment.source: For more information about how to do this, see Windows Assessment Services Setup and Configuration.
segment.target: For more information about how to do this, see Windows Assessment Services Setup and Configuration.

segment.source: Step 2: Create a Project
segment.target: Step 2: Create a Project

segment.source: A project is a collection of assets that you want to assess.
segment.target: A project is a collection of assets that you want to assess.

segment.source: It identifies multiple computers and multiple images that are a subset of all the computers and images that you added to your inventory.
segment.target: It identifies multiple computers and multiple images that are a subset of all the computers and images that you added to your inventory.

segment.source: A project provides a contextualized, manageable view of the assets of interest, and pairs up each computer with an image and answer file.
segment.target: A project provides a contextualized, manageable view of the assets of interest, and pairs up each computer with an image and answer file.

segment.source: A project does not contain assessments.
segment.target: A project does not contain assessments.

segment.source: In this step, you create a project by selecting a set of test computers from your inventory.
segment.target: In this step, you create a project by selecting a set of test computers from your inventory.

segment.source: If the computers that you select are bare metal computers, or you want to refresh the image on the test computer, you also select the images that you want to apply to each computer.
segment.target: If the computers that you select are bare metal computers, or you want to refresh the image on the test computer, you also select the images that you want to apply to each computer.

segment.source: Be sure to select images that match the architecture of your test computers.
segment.target: Be sure to select images that match the architecture of your test computers.

segment.source: Creating a project
segment.target: Creating a project

segment.source: On the Getting Started page, click Create New Project.
segment.target: On the Getting Started page, click Create New Project.

segment.source: In the Project name text box, type Project1.
segment.target: In the Project name text box, type Project1.

segment.source: In the Description text box, type a description.
segment.target: In the Description text box, type a description.

segment.source: For example, This is a test run to learn how to use assessment services in my lab environment.
segment.target: For example, This is a test run to learn how to use assessment services in my lab environment.

segment.source: In the Keywords text box, type keywords, such as Project1, and then click Next.
segment.target: In the Keywords text box, type keywords, such as Project1, and then click Next.

segment.source: In the Select machines to include in this project window, click Add and select the computer that you want to include in this project.
segment.target: In the Select machines to include in this project window, click Add and select the computer that you want to include in this project.

segment.source: Click OK and then click Next.
segment.target: Click OK and then click Next.

segment.source: In the Image Inventory window, click Add and select images to add to your project.
segment.target: In the Image Inventory window, click Add and select images to add to your project.

segment.source: Click OK and then click Finish.
segment.target: Click OK and then click Finish.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If your test computers already have a running operating system, you do not have to add images to the project.
segment.target: If your test computers already have a running operating system, you do not have to add images to the project.

segment.source: The Windows ASC home page opens.
segment.target: The Windows ASC home page opens.

segment.source: Step 3: Create a Job
segment.target: Step 3: Create a Job

segment.source: In this step, you create a job, adjust the settings, and store a job in your project.
segment.target: In this step, you create a job, adjust the settings, and store a job in your project.

segment.source: A job associates assets (a computer and a Windows image) with assessments.
segment.target: A job associates assets (a computer and a Windows image) with assessments.

segment.source: A job can contain multiple computers, the corresponding images and unattended answer files, and multiple assessments.
segment.target: A job can contain multiple computers, the corresponding images and unattended answer files, and multiple assessments.

segment.source: You can select any number of assessments to run on your test computers, however, this guide demonstrates performing a single assessment on multiple test computers.
segment.target: You can select any number of assessments to run on your test computers, however, this guide demonstrates performing a single assessment on multiple test computers.

segment.source: Add an assessment to the job
segment.target: Add an assessment to the job

segment.source: On the Home page, click Create new job.
segment.target: On the Home page, click Create new job.

segment.source: In the New Job window, in the Job Name text box type Check Drivers.
segment.target: In the New Job window, in the Job Name text box type Check Drivers.

segment.source: The following job types are available:
segment.target: The following job types are available:

segment.source: Create a custom job.
segment.target: Create a custom job.

segment.source: If you select this option, you add assessments that are designed for general use in the Windows ASC when the custom job opens.
segment.target: If you select this option, you add assessments that are designed for general use in the Windows ASC when the custom job opens.

segment.source: Create a job from a Template.
segment.target: Create a job from a Template.

segment.source: If you select this option, a template window opens and you add preconfigured jobs or assessments that have preconfigured settings.
segment.target: If you select this option, a template window opens and you add preconfigured jobs or assessments that have preconfigured settings.

segment.source: Create an energy efficiency job.
segment.target: Create an energy efficiency job.

segment.source: If you select this option, you add assessments that are designed to run as workloads to test the battery life and energy efficiency on laptops.
segment.target: If you select this option, you add assessments that are designed to run as workloads to test the battery life and energy efficiency on laptops.

segment.source: Click Create a custom job.
segment.target: Click Create a custom job.

segment.source: In the new tab in Windows ASC, the job settings are highlighted by default.
segment.target: In the new tab in Windows ASC, the job settings are highlighted by default.

segment.source: In the details pane on the right you can change the name, add a description, and add keywords to help you identify the job and the results.
segment.target: In the details pane on the right you can change the name, add a description, and add keywords to help you identify the job and the results.

segment.source: Adjust the following job settings:
segment.target: Adjust the following job settings:

segment.source: Enter keywords to help you identify the job in Search.
segment.target: Enter keywords to help you identify the job in Search.

segment.source: Choose a Failure behavior from the drop down list, and then select Stop to stop the job if there is a failure since we are only running one assessment in this job.
segment.target: Choose a Failure behavior from the drop down list, and then select Stop to stop the job if there is a failure since we are only running one assessment in this job.

segment.source: Under Configure analysis preference, select an option for when to analyze the results.
segment.target: Under Configure analysis preference, select an option for when to analyze the results.

segment.source: By default, Complete analysis on server is selected.
segment.target: By default, Complete analysis on server is selected.

segment.source: This option lets you free up the target computer for other uses, take advantage of the resources on the server to save time running the analysis, and use symbols already loaded on the server.
segment.target: This option lets you free up the target computer for other uses, take advantage of the resources on the server to save time running the analysis, and use symbols already loaded on the server.

segment.source: Under Assessment, click Add Assessments.
segment.target: Under Assessment, click Add Assessments.

segment.source: In the details pane on the right, click the plus sign () next to Driver Verification to add the assessment to the job.
segment.target: In the details pane on the right, click the plus sign () next to Driver Verification to add the assessment to the job.

segment.source: Add test computers that don’t need deployment
segment.target: Add test computers that don’t need deployment

segment.source: In the Windows ASC, under Job settings, click Overview, and then clear the Apply image check box.
segment.target: In the Windows ASC, under Job settings, click Overview, and then clear the Apply image check box.

segment.source: Under Job settings, click Assets, and then click Add to select the computers that you want run the job on.
segment.target: Under Job settings, click Assets, and then click Add to select the computers that you want run the job on.

segment.source: In the Select Evaluation Assets window, select the computers that already have a supported operating system installed, and then click Finish.
segment.target: In the Select Evaluation Assets window, select the computers that already have a supported operating system installed, and then click Finish.

segment.source: Add computers and images that do need deployment
segment.target: Add computers and images that do need deployment

segment.source: In the Windows ASC, under Job settings, click Overview, and then select the Apply image check box.
segment.target: In the Windows ASC, under Job settings, click Overview, and then select the Apply image check box.

segment.source: If you want to inject matching Plug and Play drivers from a Dynamic Driver Provisioning driver store during image deployment, select Dynamic Driver Provisioning.
segment.target: If you want to inject matching Plug and Play drivers from a Dynamic Driver Provisioning driver store during image deployment, select Dynamic Driver Provisioning.

segment.source: Under Job settings, click Assets, and then click Add to select the computers that you want run the job on.
segment.target: Under Job settings, click Assets, and then click Add to select the computers that you want run the job on.

segment.source: In the Select Evaluation Assets window, select the computers that you want to assess.
segment.target: In the Select Evaluation Assets window, select the computers that you want to assess.

segment.source: Click Next, and then click Finish.
segment.target: Click Next, and then click Finish.

segment.source: The computers appear on the right side of the Windows ASC under Evaluation assets.
segment.target: The computers appear on the right side of the Windows ASC under Evaluation assets.

segment.source: Select a computer, click Change Image, select the image that you want to apply to that computer, and then click OK.
segment.target: Select a computer, click Change Image, select the image that you want to apply to that computer, and then click OK.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: The computer and the image architecture must match, except that you can select an x86-based image to deploy to an x64-based computer.
segment.target: The computer and the image architecture must match, except that you can select an x86-based image to deploy to an x64-based computer.

segment.source: Step 4: Run the Job
segment.target: Step 4: Run the Job

segment.source: You can run a job on all the assets that you added to the project, run a job on a subset of those assets, or run different jobs on different assets that are available in the project.
segment.target: You can run a job on all the assets that you added to the project, run a job on a subset of those assets, or run different jobs on different assets that are available in the project.

segment.source: In this step, you set the run-time settings, run the job and view the progress of the job.
segment.target: In this step, you set the run-time settings, run the job and view the progress of the job.

segment.source: Running the Job
segment.target: Running the Job

segment.source: In the Windows ASC, click Run to start the job instance.
segment.target: In the Windows ASC, click Run to start the job instance.

segment.source: In the Run Job dialog, enter Job instance tag and Test Pass information, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Run Job dialog, enter Job instance tag and Test Pass information, and then click OK.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The Job instance tag identifies the iteration, installation type, or focus of comparison.
segment.target: The Job instance tag identifies the iteration, installation type, or focus of comparison.

segment.source: For example, OEM-Win7, Clean-Win7, OEM-Win8, Clean-Win8.
segment.target: For example, OEM-Win7, Clean-Win7, OEM-Win8, Clean-Win8.

segment.source: You can run a job many times.
segment.target: You can run a job many times.

segment.source: Therefore, you can have multiple instances of the job.
segment.target: Therefore, you can have multiple instances of the job.

segment.source: The Test Pass represents a milestone, a logical set of computers, or other differentiations, for example, Phase A, Phase B, Phase C, Phase D. These keywords help you identify the appropriate results when you search through a list of results, but they are not required fields.
segment.target: The Test Pass represents a milestone, a logical set of computers, or other differentiations, for example, Phase A, Phase B, Phase C, Phase D. These keywords help you identify the appropriate results when you search through a list of results, but they are not required fields.

segment.source: When the job finishes, the results are copied back to the server at %WAS-Server%relaxresults%Project%%TestPass%%JobName%%ComputerName%%JobInstanceTag%%TimeStamp%.
segment.target: When the job finishes, the results are copied back to the server at %WAS-Server%relaxresults%Project%%TestPass%%JobName%%ComputerName%%JobInstanceTag%%TimeStamp%.

segment.source: When the Results tab opens, review the progress of the job on each computer.
segment.target: When the Results tab opens, review the progress of the job on each computer.

segment.source: In the Windows ASC, in the Monitor Instances window, click View Details.
segment.target: In the Windows ASC, in the Monitor Instances window, click View Details.

segment.source: Click the name of the computer, to see additional details about the progress of the job running on that computer.
segment.target: Click the name of the computer, to see additional details about the progress of the job running on that computer.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you are applying an image to your test machine, it might take a few minutes for the task to finish.
segment.target: If you are applying an image to your test machine, it might take a few minutes for the task to finish.

segment.source: Step 5: Review the Results
segment.target: Step 5: Review the Results

segment.source: By default, when you open multiple results in Windows ASC, you get a summary view of the results.
segment.target: By default, when you open multiple results in Windows ASC, you get a summary view of the results.

segment.source: The summary view displays each job instance as a column.
segment.target: The summary view displays each job instance as a column.

segment.source: Below the overview tables, metrics for each assessment in the job instance appear as a chart.
segment.target: Below the overview tables, metrics for each assessment in the job instance appear as a chart.

segment.source: This summary contains information about the computer, the job that was run, and overall metrics that were measured.
segment.target: This summary contains information about the computer, the job that was run, and overall metrics that were measured.

segment.source: It provides a visual comparison of the same metric across several job instances, and lets you select which metrics are displayed.
segment.target: It provides a visual comparison of the same metric across several job instances, and lets you select which metrics are displayed.

segment.source: This view of the results can help you identify individual computers in your lab environment that need quality improvements.
segment.target: This view of the results can help you identify individual computers in your lab environment that need quality improvements.

segment.source: In this step, you view the results for the completed job.
segment.target: In this step, you view the results for the completed job.

segment.source: Review the Results
segment.target: Review the Results

segment.source: Click the back arrow to return to the job instance view.
segment.target: Click the back arrow to return to the job instance view.

segment.source: Verify that the job is complete, select the job, and then click View Results.
segment.target: Verify that the job is complete, select the job, and then click View Results.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The View Results button is unavailable until a job instance is complete and highlighted.
segment.target: The View Results button is unavailable until a job instance is complete and highlighted.

segment.source: On the Results Overview page, review the total number of Errors and Warnings that were reported for each computer in the Overview: Overall issues table.
segment.target: On the Results Overview page, review the total number of Errors and Warnings that were reported for each computer in the Overview: Overall issues table.

segment.source: All visible metrics have bar charts under the overview tables.
segment.target: All visible metrics have bar charts under the overview tables.

segment.source: In one of the assessment metric rows, such as Driver verification: Devices Missing drivers click Sort to arrange the graph in an ascending or descending order.
segment.target: In one of the assessment metric rows, such as Driver verification: Devices Missing drivers click Sort to arrange the graph in an ascending or descending order.

segment.source: Select the first bar in the chart to highlight the corresponding column in the Overview.
segment.target: Select the first bar in the chart to highlight the corresponding column in the Overview.

segment.source: Click View details in the lower-right corner, to view detailed job results for the selected computer.
segment.target: Click View details in the lower-right corner, to view detailed job results for the selected computer.

segment.source: Expand the metric that has the highest value, and select an individual issue to see more information in the details pane on the right.
segment.target: Expand the metric that has the highest value, and select an individual issue to see more information in the details pane on the right.

segment.source: In the Issues pane, expand one of the issues to see what is recommended for remediation.
segment.target: In the Issues pane, expand one of the issues to see what is recommended for remediation.

segment.source: For example, removing extra drivers is recommended if you have devices with multiple drivers.
segment.target: For example, removing extra drivers is recommended if you have devices with multiple drivers.

segment.source: If extra drivers are listed, browse to the file location for that computer, specified under Extra drivers that can be removed, and delete extra drivers.
segment.target: If extra drivers are listed, browse to the file location for that computer, specified under Extra drivers that can be removed, and delete extra drivers.

segment.source: When you run the job again, you should notice that you do not have extra drivers.
segment.target: When you run the job again, you should notice that you do not have extra drivers.

segment.source: Conclusion
segment.target: Conclusion

segment.source: In this step-by-step guide, you installed and configured Windows Assessment Services, created an inventory of test computers and images, setup dynamic driver provisioning, created a project, ran a job with the Driver verification assessment and reviewed the assessment results.
segment.target: In this step-by-step guide, you installed and configured Windows Assessment Services, created an inventory of test computers and images, setup dynamic driver provisioning, created a project, ran a job with the Driver verification assessment and reviewed the assessment results.

segment.source: This is a basic scenario.
segment.target: This is a basic scenario.

segment.source: More advanced scenarios include the following:
segment.target: More advanced scenarios include the following:

segment.source: Running multiple assessments on test computers.
segment.target: Running multiple assessments on test computers.

segment.source: Running the same set of assessments on a single computer, but using different images.
segment.target: Running the same set of assessments on a single computer, but using different images.

segment.source: Viewing comparison reports for assessment jobs that have different images.
segment.target: Viewing comparison reports for assessment jobs that have different images.

segment.source: Capturing and deploying images of other formats.
segment.target: Capturing and deploying images of other formats.

segment.source: Next Steps
segment.target: Next Steps

segment.source: Create another job and try other assessments, add more computers, or use a different image.
segment.target: Create another job and try other assessments, add more computers, or use a different image.

segment.source: If you ran the last job using Windows Assessment Services to deploy Windows to computers, you can save time by assessing computers that already have Windows 8 installed.
segment.target: If you ran the last job using Windows Assessment Services to deploy Windows to computers, you can save time by assessing computers that already have Windows 8 installed.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Windows Assessment Services
segment.target: Windows Assessment Services

segment.source: Windows Assessment Services common scenarios
segment.target: Windows Assessment Services common scenarios

segment.source: Analyze results on another device
segment.target: Analyze results on another device
